Right, it was my mistake.

I copied and pasted the regex into the crawler-b=
eans.cxml but in that case there is no unicode escaping. (The unicode escap=
ing is done by the Java bytecode compiler.)

Thanks for your reply

Bertran=
d

--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> wrote:
=
>
> Are you looking at the source code? Literal strings in Java use '\' as =

> the escape character, so to include a '\' in a string requires '\\'. 
> =
(And thus also, as regex patterns use '\' as an escape, to match a 
> singl=
e literal '\' requires "\\\\" in a regex in Java source code!)
> 
> - Gordo=
n @ IA
> 
> bertrand.dechoux wrote:
> > Hi,
> > 
> > I have been looking at=
 the MatchesFilePatternDecideRule in Heritrix 3 and all patterns start with=
 ".*(?i)(\\.". Shouldn't it be ".*(?i)(\." ?
> > 
> > An example : "http://=
msoft.com/door.doc" would be matched by ".*(?i)(\.doc" but not by ".*(?i)(\=
\.doc".
